awd_abstract_narration:
There is an increasing recognition of the deep time co-evolutionary relationship between humans and many psychoactive and medicinal plants, yet much remains to be learned about their past use. Researchers aim to understand the complex evolutionary processes through which societies and individuals interacted with ancient drugs including tobacco, cannabis, caffeinated teas, coffee, chocolate, and opiates. Few adults today have not used or been impacted by one or more of these intoxicants, many of which have in recent times been refined into incredibly potent and addictive substances, with global health consequences. Archaeology offers a deep-time perspective into plant domestication, coupled human-plant interactions, and addiction and drug use by people, who used an array of plants not only as food but also for social, ceremonial, recreational, and medicinal reasons. Chemical residue analysis of alkaloid biomarkers in ancient materials offers a novel means of approaching these issues; recent studies have produced compelling results demonstrating the global scale and deep time use of intoxicant plants. However, major challenges remain, particularly in terms of baseline experimental method development in controlled laboratory settings. Washington State University (WSU) scientists Dr. Shannon Tushingham and Dr. David Gang will undertake research designed to expand frontiers in the biomolecular archaeology of psychoactive plants through a 3-year program of hypothesis testing and experimentation in controlled laboratory settings aimed at developing rigorous methods and cutting-edge technologies that will expand understanding of past use of psychoactives among global societies. Analytical methods include liquid and gas chromatography-time of flight mass spectrometry (LC-TOFMS and GC-TOFMS), Matrix-assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Mass Spectrometry (MALDI-MS), and metabolomics research tools to chemically fingerprint key drug plants and test assumptions concerning their use in the past. 

The WSU team focuses on two exciting research avenues: (1) ancient metabolomics, which employs powerful metabolomic profiling tools to evaluate the complete chemical fingerprint of plants and ancient residues, with the goal of discriminating plants to the species level, and (2) dental calculus studies, directed at refining identification of intoxicant compounds in human dental calculus (mineralized plaque), which permits identification of drug use of substances including tobacco, cannabis, and opioids to the individual level. Improved dental calculus methods will provide researchers the capability to ask anthropologically significant questions about intoxicant use by individuals of varied circumstances and societal groups (e.g., use patterns by age, gender, status, health categories) and previously "invisible" users (i.e., those not buried with artifacts indicating use such as pipes), as well as effects on oral health, past and present. Hypothesis testing involves method-building experiments with laboratory-produced artifacts (e.g., ceramic pots brewed with cacao, cassina tea, etc.) and modern dental calculus (obtained through a collaboration with the University of Washington Department of Periodontics), as well as a series of method validation/ directed pilot studies on archaeological artifacts. Undergraduate and graduate students are involved in every stage and gain valuable archaeometric skills. Broader impacts are expanded through interdisciplinary educational, public dissemination, and collaborative projects, and involve public displays/ presentations, research partnerships with Tribal communities, and educational and outreach projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Many psychoactive plants used by prehistoric humans have more recently been refined into incredibly potent and addictive substances, with global health consequences. Indeed, few adults today have not used or been impacted by one or more of the plants we study (tobacco, cannabis, tea, coffee, chocolate, opiates), yet few realize the deep time history of humanity's interactions with these plants.   With NSF funding, our interdisciplinary project team of archaeologists and analytical chemists investigated the history of psychoactive plant use through the expansion of biomolecular identification methods and application on archaeological materials from global contexts. NSF support permitted us to significantly advance residue extraction and chemical fingerprinting techniques and refine our ability to identify and characterize psychoactive ancient residues from archaeological materials. These studies built upon a previous NSF Archaeometry funded research that provided the foundation for our intensive program of laboratory experimentation and mass spectrometry analysis of alkaloid-bearing plants. Over a four-year period, we met four objectives: (1) Improved biochemical methods of discriminating intoxicant plants to the species-level through ancient metabolomics, (2) Improved biochemical methods of identifying intoxicant plant use by humans to the individual level through dental calculus, (3) Completed method validation projects through directed pilot studies on archaeological artifacts, and (4) Expanded broader impacts through learning projects, public dissemination, and collaborative projects.  Through the NSF and a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) supplement, the project the project provided numerous educational outcomes and research opportunities for students, and facilitated the hiring of students who are themselves members of Tribal communities to contribute to the scientific study of Native peoples. The study involved and provided training for numerous undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, Indigenous communities, and national and international colleagues. Major activities involved the innovation and refinement of extraction methods through experimental archaeology and work with archaeological artifacts and dental calculus specimens. Our team also significantly expanded biomolecular analysis of a suite of medicinal and ceremonial plants used by Indigenous communities in the Americas, Africa, and Asia, many of which were grown from seed in WSU greenhouses or collected in the field or research arboretums. Similarly, we successfully explored the application of a broader suite of statistical tools for data processing in untargeted metabolomics analysis. Specific archaeological research activities included the analysis of mortars from Arizona, pipes from Arizona, Washington, British Columbia (CAN), and Benin, as well as human dental calculus from California and Thailand. The research provided significant new tools and capabilities that permit an expanded understanding of human use of psychoactive plants in ancient societies. Until this study, dental calculus studies applied to ancient drug use had great potential but lacked method development in controlled laboratory settings. We explored the science of ancient metabolomics and improved dental calculus methods provide cutting edge tools that allowed us to ask anthropologically significant questions about intoxicant plant use by individuals of varied circumstances and societal groups (e.g., patterns of drug use by age, gender, status, health categories) as well as previously "invisible" users (i.e. users not buried with artifacts indicating use, i.e., pipes). Outreach and dissemination activities featured the organization of a major biomolecular archaeology symposium at the Society for American Archaeology annual meeting, numerous papers and presentations at international and national scientific conferences, guest lectures and research presentations in university classes. Public science communication was expanded through numerous outreach projects including numerous public presentations, an exhibit at the WSU Museum of Anthropology, an educational website, and dissemination through multiple outlets (radio, podcasts, print and online venues). Native American collaboration involved consultation, presentation of results to communities, discussions with traditional users of ritual plants, work with Tribal partners and coauthors. Students were involved in every stage and learned valuable skills through participation with experiments, extractions, and chemical analyses. The project funded undergraduate assistants and graduate students and provide opportunities for graduate students (e.g. in research, seminars, and WSU graduate class, Residue Analysis and Experimental Archaeology).  Results were presented in the classroom, in seminar series, and academic conferences, and published in numerous scholarly journals. The study promotes understanding of the cultural context and ancient nature of psychoactive plant use. For example, the work is relevant to the development of culturally relevant tobacco cessation projects for American Indian groups. A growing number of health advocates are recognizing the importance of developing a cultural framework of smoking traditions that recognizes the importance of tobacco in native tradition in cessation programs and even incorporating residue studies in these programs. In sum, through NSF research we developed a new set of analytical tools that may be applied in similar studies investigating the spread and use of ritual and medicinal psychoactive plants in the ancient Americas and beyond. Method development will ultimately increase the number and range of potential archaeological in the future.  


Last Modified: 03/11/2024
Modified by: Shannon Tushingham
